title: How climate change affects animal migration
intro: Climate change can affect the way animals migrate, but did you know that some animal migration could be used to fight climate change? Neil and Beth discuss this and teach you some new vocabulary.
this_week_question: How many animals are thought to take part in The Great Migration, the annual migration of animals around the Serengeti in Tanzania and the Maasai Mara in Kenya?
a)    1 million b)    1.5 million c)    2.5 million
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: move to another place because of the weather or temperature

vocab.text: what kind of (something, e.g. price, distance) are we talking?
vocab.desc: used to rephrase a question that starts with how much or how far
something nobody knows about that gives you an advantage over a problem or enemy
used to explain the size or importance of something, particularly when that thing is difficult to imagine

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Beth.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. You can find a transcript and worksheet for this podcast on our website bbclearningenglish.com.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: So Neil, today we're talking about animal migration: that's the movement of animals from one place to another, usually because of the weather or temperature.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes. For example, wildebeest are famous for their migration. They travel around the Serengeti in Tanzania and the Maasai Mara in Kenya every year depending on the rain. It's often called The Great Migration.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Yes, and I have a question for you about this, Neil. How many animals are thought to take part in The Great Migration every year? Is it:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, I don't know… but I'm going to guess 2.5 million.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: OK. I'll reveal the answer at the end of the programme. Now, wildebeest are not the only animals who travel large distances.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That's right. Many sharks also migrate – they move to a different place because of the weather or temperature.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Trisha Atwood researches sharks and their migration for Utah State University and explained more to BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

transcript.author: Trisha
transcript.text: Animals migrate for all types of reasons. So, some of them migrate for food resources, things like mating or for giving birth.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, animals can migrate for food, mating and giving birth. Host of BBC World Service's The Climate Question, Sophie Eastaugh, wanted to know more.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: And what kind of distances are we talking with these migrations? Are they covering huge swathes of ocean?

transcript.author: Trisha
transcript.text: Some of these shark species can travel massive distances. We've seen great white sharks that have travelled from the coast off of Perth, Australia, all the way to South Africa.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Sophie asks, " What kinds of distances are we talking with these migrations?" This is an informal way to ask, "How far are the migrations?" We can rephrase lots of questions in this way. For example, you could ask " What kind of price are we talking ?" to ask how much something costs.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sophie goes on to ask whether sharks travel across huge swathes of ocean. Swathes of ocean means large areas of ocean.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Yes, and in fact, sharks do travel across large areas. For example, great white sharks can travel from Australia to South Africa. That is a long way to swim!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But, as climate change causes changes to the temperature of the ocean, it's changing the way that sharks migrate .

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: This is a problem; sharks scare away other creatures, such as sea turtles, and these creatures eat seagrass, which absorbs a lot of carbon from the atmosphere.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So, basically, when the sharks are around, there's more seagrass on the ocean floor and so more carbon is absorbed. So, sharks can actually help fight climate change.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Yes. In fact, lots of species that migrate are really important for fighting climate change. Let's hear more from BBC World Service programme, The Climate Question.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: Sharks aren't the only migratory animal that acts as a secret weapon against climate change.

transcript.author: Trisha
transcript.text: Research that we worked on shows that by just managing about 10 groups of animals we could be taking out or sequestering more CO2 from the atmosphere by about six gigatonnes of carbon per year.

transcript.author: Sophie
transcript.text: So, for perspective , some experts say that we need to suck 10 gigatonnes of CO2 a year out of the atmosphere to meet our climate goals.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Sophie says that many animals that migrate , like sharks, are a secret weapon against climate change. A secret weapon is something nobody knows about that will give you an advantage over a problem or enemy.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: By protecting sharks and other animals that migrate , Trisha's research shows that we could be sequestering six gigatonnes of carbon dioxide, or CO2, a year from the atmosphere. Sequester means remove and store the carbon, for example in plants like seagrass.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Six gigatonnes is a lot of carbon! Sophie says that, for perspective , it's about 60% of the amount of carbon dioxide that some scientists believe we need to remove from the atmosphere each year. We can use the phrase ' for perspective ' to explain the size or importance of something, particularly when it's difficult to imagine that thing.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Alongside sharks, another species that Trisha believes is important to helping remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere is the wildebeest.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, and that reminds me of your question, Beth. You asked me how many animals take part in The Great Migration, and I think I went for option c) 2.5 million. Was I right?

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: You weren't, I'm afraid. The answer was b) 1.5 million, so still a lot of animals. OK. Let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with migrate : move to a different place. For animals, this is usually because of the weather or temperature.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We can use the structure ' W hat kind of (something) are we talking? ' to rephrase a question more informally, particularly one about distance, cost or numbers. For example, " What kind of distance are we talking ?"

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Swathes means large areas of something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A secret weapon is something nobody knows about that gives you an advantage over a problem or enemy.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: If you sequester something, such as carbon dioxide, you remove it and store it.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And we can use the phrase 'for perspective' to explain the size or importance of something, particularly if that thing is difficult to imagine.

transcript.author: Beth
transcript.text: Once again, our six minutes are up. Why not test what you've learned using the interactive quiz on our website? Bye for now!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye.
